title: US sought to lure Nicolás Maduro's pilot into betraying the Venezuelan leader
reference_summary: An agent for Homeland Security Investigations spent more than 16 months trying to recruit Venezulean President Nicolás Maduro's chief pilot, Gen. Bitner Villegas, to secretly divert the Maduro's plane so the U.S. could capture him, according to interviews, text messages, and documents reviewed by the Associated Press. The plan began in April 2024 after a tip revealed Maduro's jets were undergoing repairs in the Dominican Republic. The agent, Edwin Lopez, met the pilots in an airport hangar, ultimately pitching Villegas a lucrative deal to fly Maduro to a location where U.S. authorities could seize him. Even after retiring in July 2025, Lopez continued contacting Villegas through encrypted apps, including messages referencing the U.S. bounty on Maduro — raised to $50 million after Trump returned to the White House and escalated operations against Venezuela, including CIA covert actions and military strikes on suspected drug smugglers. The pilot ultimately rejected the proposal and later appeared on Venezuelan state TV alongside a top official, who praised his loyalty.

title: Trump administration sued over $100K fee for skilled worker visas
reference_summary: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which represents more than 3 million American businesses, has sued the Trump administration over a new $100,000 fee imposed on H-1B visa petitions, arguing the fee would make the program too expensive for employers and harm companies that rely on skilled foreign workers. Trump's executive order applies to new H-1B requests and requires payment before entry, with the administration calling the fee lawful and necessary to reform what it says is an abused visa system. Tech leaders, including Elon Musk, Microsoft's Satya Nadella, and Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai—each of whom began their careers in the U.S. while on H-1B visas—criticized the move, saying the program helps the U.S. attract top global talent. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick defended the fee, saying companies should decide whether a worker is worth the cost or instead hire an American.

title: Sikh man with tumour held by US immigration denied medical care - family
reference_summary: Paramjit Singh, 48, a U.S. green-card holder from Indiana with a brain tumour and heart condition, has been detained by ICE for over two months after being stopped at Chicago O'Hare on July 30 and moved to a Clay County detention center. Authorities say Singh was detained for a 1999 conviction after using a public phone without paying — for which Singh served 10 days and paid a $4,137 fine — and an alleged 2008 forgery case, which authorities cited to stay Singh's release on a $10,000 bond granted by an immigration judge. His family and lawyer say there are no active charges against him and call it a case of mistaken identity. His attorney, Louis Angeles, says Singh “is not getting the medical help he needs,“ and Singh's family complains about limited contact and a delayed second brain-tumor surgery. Singh's case is set for October 14, amid a broader Trump-era immigration crackdown that critics say is sweeping up long-time residents, citing the recent deportation of 73-year-old Harjit Kaur as an example.

title: Two dozen states sue White House over food stamps suspension amid shutdown
reference_summary: This week more than two dozen states, led by New York, California, and Massachusetts, sued the Trump administration to force the U.S. Department of Agriculture to continue issuing Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits during the federal government shutdown. The lawsuit argues that USDA is legally required to use its roughly $6 billion contingency fund to maintain food aid for nearly 42 million Americans, despite the agency's announcement that no benefits will be issued on November 1. State attorneys general say the administration is creating unnecessary hardship and political fear, noting that SNAP costs about $8 billion per month and is the country's largest nutrition program. USDA officials claim the funds are not legally available for regular benefits, although a prior USDA shutdown plan — since removed from its website — stated Congress intended SNAP to continue during a shutdown.

title: Brigitte Macron's life 'deteriorated' after alleged cyber-bullying, daughter says
reference_summary: The stepdaughter of French President Emmanuel Macron testified in a Paris court that online conspiracy theories falsely claiming her mother is transgender have harmed the French First Lady's health, daily life, and family. The case involves 10 defendants — including an elected official, an independent journalist, and an online fortune-teller — accused of spreading unsubstantiated claims about Brigitte Macron's gender and sexuality. Prosecutors are seeking suspended prison sentences of three to 12 months and fines up to €8,000. Tiphaine Auzière, 41, said the harassment has worsened her mother's well-being, forced her to scrutinize her appearance, and led to her grandchildren being taunted at school. The Macrons plan to present evidence proving the First Lady is a biological woman in a case against U.S. influencer Candace Owens.

title: Trump appeals against conviction in hush-money case
reference_summary: Donald Trump has filed an appeal seeking to overturn his May 2024 conviction in the hush-money case, arguing that presidential immunity shields him from prosecution. Trump was found guilty on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records related to reimbursing lawyer Michael Cohen for a $130,000 payment to adult film star Stormy Daniels before the 2016 election. Although a New York judge sentenced Trump to an unconditional discharge — given his impending return to the White House — Trump's lawyers call the case politically motivated and argue that key evidence should have been excluded under the Supreme Court's later ruling that presidents have broad immunity for “official acts.“ Trump's appeal will be reviewed by the New York Appellate Division, First Department.

title: US transportation secretary says he'll revoke $160m from California over non-citizen truck licenses
reference_summary: U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said he is preparing to revoke $160 million in federal funds from California and potentially strip the state of its authority to issue commercial driver's licenses, alleging California is illegally granting said licenses to non-citizens. California officials reject the claim, saying the state is complying with new federal rules that took effect on September 29 and arguing the administration has “no legitimate basis“ to withhold funds. The Department of Transportation tightened CDL rules for non-citizens last month after three fatal crashes that officials say were caused by immigrant truck drivers. A nationwide audit of commercial licenses found improperly issued licenses in multiple states, including California, Colorado, Pennsylvania, and Texas. Duffy claims California issued tens of thousands of licenses to people who should not have them and failed to enforce English-language requirements. California disputes the findings and says its CDL holders have lower crash rates than the national average.

title: Argentina's Milei wins big in midterms with 'chainsaw' austerity
reference_summary: Argentina's President Javier Milei and his party, La Libertad Avanza, won a landslide victory in the midterm elections, taking nearly 41% of the vote and gaining major increases in both chambers of Congress (13 of 24 Senate seats and 64 of 127 lower-house seats). The result strengthens Milei's ability to advance his aggressive austerity and free-market reforms — deep cuts to state spending, deregulation, and mass layoffs — which have lowered inflation and the deficit but have also led to job losses, reduced services, and economic pain for many Argentines. U.S. President Donald Trump praised Milei and tied future U.S. financial support, including a potential $40 billion lifeline, to Milei's political momentum. Supporters say Milei is restoring economic stability after decades of mismanagement, while critics warn that cuts to pensions, healthcare, and disability services are worsening poverty and unemployment. The election gives Milei a stronger mandate heading into the next political cycle, raising the stakes over whether voters will feel relief from austerity—or lose patience with the pain.

title: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica - video
reference_summary: Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday as a Category 5 storm, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center. Before landfall, seven storm-related deaths were reported across the Caribbean — three in Jamaica, three in Haiti, and one in the Dominican Republic. More than 240,000 people in Jamaica lost power, and about 25% of the country's telecommunications system was offline.

title: Alassane Ouattara wins landslide fourth term as Ivory Coast's president
reference_summary: Alassane Ouattara won Ivory Coast's presidential election by a landslide, securing 89.77% of the vote and a fourth term, according to provisional results from the Independent Electoral Commission. The 83-year-old ran against four lesser-known candidates after major opposition figures Laurent Gbagbo and Tidjane Thiam were barred from running. Voter turnout was low — about 50% — especially in urban centers, which observers say contributed to a largely peaceful vote compared with past elections marked by violence. Ouattara, in power since 2011, has overseen economic growth but faces accusations of cronyism and suppressing dissent.

title: Hurricane Melissa: a visual guide to Jamaica's strongest storm since 1851
reference_summary: Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday as a catastrophic Category 5 storm, the strongest ever recorded on the island since 1851. With sustained winds near 180 mph and moving slowly at about 7 mph, the storm is expected to linger over the country, causing catastrophic flooding, landslides, and severe structural damage. Airports shut down, evacuations were ordered, and officials warned of storm surges up to 13 feet, with concerns about damage to coastal hospitals and mass displacement. Scientists note the storm's unusually rapid intensification over abnormally warm ocean waters, linking the conditions to climate-driven ocean heating.

title: Mass killings reported in Sudanese city seized by paramilitary group
reference_summary: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have seized control of El Fasher in Sudan's Darfur region. Reports from activists, the UN, and Yale University's Humanitarian Research Lab indicate mass killings, summary executions, and ethnically targeted attacks against non-Arab groups including the Fur, Zaghawa, and Berti. Video and satellite imagery suggest door-to-door killings, bodies in streets, and burned civilian areas. One activist group accused the RSF of executing more than 2,000 civilians in recent days. The UN warns of “ethnically motivated violations and atrocities,“ while communications from the city have been cut, leaving families learning of loved ones' deaths through circulating execution footage. The RSF's capture of El Fasher gives the group control over all five state capitals in Darfur, marking a major turning point in Sudan's civil war and raising concerns that the country could face partition.

title: Man deported to Laos despite US court order blocking his removal, attorneys say
reference_summary: Immigration authorities deported Chanthila “Shawn“ Souvannarath, a 44-year-old father living in Alabama, to Laos despite a federal judge's order blocking his removal while he pursued what the court called a “substantial claim of U.S. citizenship.“ Souvannarath, who was born in a refugee camp in Thailand and brought to the U.S. as an infant, argues his citizenship derives from his father, a naturalized American. The ACLU of Louisiana called the deportation a “stunning violation of a federal court order,“ saying ICE ignored the law and separated a family. The case highlights tension between the Trump administration's mass-deportation push and court limits on deportations, including previous incidents of U.S. citizens being removed.

title: World's oldest serving head of state declared winner in Cameroon election
reference_summary: Cameroon's 92-year-old president, Paul Biya, has won reelection with 53.7% of the vote, extending his rule into an eighth term that could see him in power until nearly the age of 100. Challenger Issa Tchiroma Bakary, who received 35.2%, rejected the result as a “masquerade,“ claiming he actually won based on tallies his campaign collected. The election results sparked protests, clashes with security forces, and reports of internet restrictions and bans on public gatherings in major cities. Biya, in power since 1982 and having removed term limits in 2008, has long maintained tight control over the Central African nation through repression of opposition and unrest.

title: Bill Gates calls for climate fight to shift focus from global heating to 'improving lives'
reference_summary: Bill Gates has published a memo calling for a “strategic pivot“ on climate efforts, arguing that instead of focusing primarily on limiting global temperature rise, the world should prioritize reducing poverty and disease, which he says pose a greater threat to most people. Gates wrote that climate change will bring serious impacts, especially for poorer nations, but rejected what he called a “doomsday view,“ saying humanity will still be able to live and thrive. His comments contrast sharply with UN Secretary General António Guterres, who warned the world has already failed to avoid surpassing the 1.5°C limit and faces “devastating consequences“ and potential tipping points in places like the Amazon and Antarctica.

title: Venezuela's Maduro says US 'fabricating war' as it deploys world's largest warship
reference_summary: After conducting multiple airstrikes on vessels in the region, the U.S. has deployed the world's largest aircraft carrier, the USS Gerald R. Ford, to the Caribbean as part of what President Donald Trump calls a campaign against drug traffickers. Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro accused the U.S. of “fabricating a new war“ and trying to remove him from power, as the U.S. does not recognize his 2024 reelection. The Pentagon says the deployment is meant to disrupt narcotics trafficking, though analysts note Venezuela plays only a minor role in the drug trade and argue the move signals potential regime-change pressure. Trump has openly discussed possible “land action,“ and U.S. strikes in the region have already killed at least 43 people, prompting members of Congress, both Democrat and Republican, to question the legality and authority for the operations.

title: Jamaica braces for catastrophic winds and flooding as Hurricane Melissa approaches
reference_summary: Hurricane Melissa struck southwestern Jamaica on Tuesday as a catastrophic Category 5 storm with 185-mph winds, tying records for the strongest Atlantic hurricane ever at landfall. Flooding, landslides, and widespread power outages were reported, with roughly 540,000 customers — about 77% of the island — losing electricity and nearly 15,000 people sheltering in emergency centers. Officials warned of storm surges up to 13 feet and reported hospital damage, trapped families, and roofs ripped from buildings, though confirmed deaths in Jamaica were not yet reported at landfall. The hurricane is expected to move toward Cuba next, where evacuations are underway.

title: Wrongfully imprisoned for more than 40 years, US man now faces deportation to India
reference_summary: Subramanyam “Subu“ Vedam, who spent 43 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, was exonerated and released, only to be immediately detained by U.S. immigration authorities, who plan to deport him to India under a decades-old deportation order. Vedam was convicted in the early 1980s of murdering his former roommate despite no physical evidence, but new evidence led prosecutors to drop the case this month. ICE argues the deportation order still applies because a separate drug conviction from the 1980s remains on his record. Vedam's family and lawyers say he has lived in the U.S. since infancy, has no meaningful ties to India, and that deportation after his wrongful imprisonment would be “another terrible wrong.“

title: Some of the earliest written notes in western musical history discovered in Pennsylvania
reference_summary: Researchers examining a ninth-century vellum manuscript in a private collection discovered what they believe are some of the earliest written musical notations in Western history. The markings—dots and characters written above the word “alleluia“ in a Latin sacramentary used during Easter mass—appear to guide singers on pitch rises and falls. Historian Nathan Raab, who identified the notations, says the document may predate other early Western music manuscripts such as the Laon Gradual and the St. Gall Cantatorium. If confirmed, it would be one of the earliest known examples of Western musical notation and the oldest such example in private hands.

title: Texas attorney general sues Tylenol makers over autism claims
reference_summary: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton sued Tylenol makers Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, alleging the companies hid risks that the popular over-the-counter medication poses to children's brain development and falsely marketed it as safe for pregnant women. The lawsuit follows Donald Trump's recent promotion of an unproven link between Tylenol use during pregnancy and autism, though medical groups, including the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, say no credible evidence supports such a link. Kenvue says the claims are misinformation, and the FDA has stated that a causal relationship between acetaminophen and autism has not been established. Paxton seeks to block the companies from advertising Tylenol as safe for pregnant women, echoing a similar 2022 lawsuit that was dismissed for lack of scientific proof.

title: 'Storm of the century': record-breaking Hurricane Melissa hits Jamaica
reference_summary: Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica as a Category 5 storm, the strongest to ever hit the island since record-keeping began in 1851. The storm caused catastrophic flooding, landslides, widespread power outages, and structural failures, prompting Prime Minister Andrew Holness to declare Jamaica a disaster area. Melissa's sustained winds reached around 185 mph, knocking out power to major parishes and damaging hospitals as residents sheltered from flying debris and rising waters. Scientists say the storm's explosive intensification is linked to unusually warm ocean temperatures driven by climate change. The hurricane is expected to move next toward Cuba and the Bahamas.

title: US kills 14 in strikes on four alleged drug boats in Pacific
reference_summary: U.S. forces killed 14 people in strikes on four boats in the Pacific that the Pentagon says were being used to traffic drugs, bringing the total death toll from similar strikes to at least 57. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said the strikes were carried out on President Donald Trump's orders, part of a broader campaign now expanding from the Caribbean into the Pacific. The recent actions have drawn regional and international criticism, with Mexico's president objecting and experts and members of Congress questioning the legality and lack of due process. Colombia and Venezuela have also condemned the strikes, warning they are escalating tensions amid U.S. military buildup in the region.

title: China controls the rare earths the world buys - can Trump's new deals change that?
reference_summary: During his trip to Asia this week, U.S. President Donald Trump signed multiple deals with Japan, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, and Cambodia to secure rare earth minerals and reduce U.S. dependence on China, which controls roughly 70% of global rare earth processing. The agreements range from investment commitments to preferential export rules favoring U.S. buyers, though many are non-binding and thin on details. The U.S. also recently struck an $8.5 billion cooperation deal with Australia to help build refining capacity outside China. Experts say diversifying rare earth supply chains will take years and require massive investment and strict environmental regulation, since processing rare earths is costly and highly polluting.

title: Atlanta journalist says he 'won't be the only one deported by Trump officials
reference_summary: Mario Guevara, an Emmy-winning journalist and longtime U.S. resident, was deported from the U.S. by the Trump administration on October 3 and believes he may be the first immigrant journalist removed while reporting. Guevara, who fled El Salvador in 2004 and had a work permit, was arrested while livestreaming an anti-Trump protest in Atlanta. Prosecutors dropped charges, but immigration authorities reopened a decade-old asylum case and deported him. He argues the move was retaliation for his reporting, while the administration claims he was deported solely because he lacked legal status. Guevara warns that journalists — especially immigrants — could face more aggressive targeting, saying, “They see the media as an enemy.“

title: US imposes sanctions on left-wing Colombian President Petro
reference_summary: The U.S. has imposed sanctions on Colombian President Gustavo Petro, accusing him of failing to curb drug trafficking and allowing cartels to “flourish“ in his country, a move that escalates a growing conflict between Petro and U.S. President Donald Trump. The U.S. Treasury says cocaine production has surged to record levels under Petro, and also sanctioned Colombia's interior minister, Petro's wife, and his eldest son, blocking them from accessing their U.S. assets. Petro called the sanctions “arbitrary“ and argued he has fought drug trafficking for decades, blaming rising coca production on his predecessor and pointing to American and European demand as the real driver. The dispute comes amid U.S. strikes on drug-smuggling boats — attacks that killed Colombians and which Petro called “murder.“ After the U.S. recently revoked Colombia's status as an ally in the drug war, Colombia responded by saying it would stop buying U.S. weapons.

title: Grave fears for civilians after Sudanese paramilitary claims capture of El Fasher
reference_summary: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) claim to have captured El Fasher, the last major army-held city in Sudan's Darfur region, deepening fears for the hundreds of thousands of civilians trapped there after more than a year under siege. The army and local militias insist they are still resisting, but reports indicate fighters have pushed deeper into the city, cut off escape routes, and may be killing civilians trying to flee. Humanitarian agencies warn that about 260,000 people remain trapped without aid, amid telecommunications blackouts and credible allegations of executions, artillery strikes on shelters, and arrests of journalists. If confirmed, the fall of El Fasher gives the RSF control over all five Darfur states, raising the possibility of Sudan's effective partition. News of El Fasher's capture comes amid accusations that foreign governments are fueling the conflict with weapons.

title: Trump administration will revamp ICE leadership in quest to intensify deportations
reference_summary: The Trump administration is planning a leadership shake-up at Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) to accelerate mass deportations, according to reports from multiple outlets. The White House is reportedly frustrated that ICE is arresting far fewer immigrants than goals set by senior adviser Stephen Miller — about 1,178 per day versus the target of 3,000, and well below Trump's pledge to deport 1 million people in his first year. NBC News reports that “at least a dozen“ ICE field office directors could be reassigned and replaced with Border Patrol officials. Border Patrol has recently faced criticism for aggressive operations, including a Home Depot parking-lot raid in Los Angeles and an incident where an agent shot a U.S. citizen in Chicago. The Department of Homeland Security said only that it is “laser focused on results“ and has no personnel changes to announce yet.

title: Russian forces gain foothold in strategic Ukrainian town
reference_summary: Russia is intensifying its offensive in eastern Ukraine and has gained a foothold in the key logistics hub of Pokrovsk, according to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. He said Russian troops outnumber Ukrainian forces roughly 8-to-1 in the area, with about 200 Russian soldiers now inside the city, though he denied claims that Ukrainian troops are fully encircled. Russia's defense ministry says its forces have surrounded Ukrainian units near the main railway station and cleared one district, while Ukraine says it has repelled 79 attacks around Pokrovsk since Monday. The battle is complicated by drone warfare and bad weather that limits Ukraine's visibility. Zelensky urged European allies for long-term financial support and said he hopes upcoming talks between Donald Trump and China's Xi Jinping will push China to scale back support for Russia.

title: Indian doctors in US worry higher H-1B fee may destroy rural healthcare
reference_summary: The U.S. is considering raising H-1B visa fees to $100,000, alarming the roughly 50,000 India-trained doctors who staff underserved rural areas and rely on H-1B status. Although the Trump administration has clarified that the fee won't apply to already-issued visas, uncertainty remains for future doctors, and hospitals fear they won't be able to afford new hires. Rural communities depend heavily on foreign physicians — 1 in 4 doctors in the U.S. is foreign-trained, and many serve where American graduates refuse to work. The American Medical Association and more than 50 medical groups warn that the fee could worsen a projected 124,000-doctor shortage by 2034 and reduce access to care. Supporters say stricter immigration protects U.S. jobs, but studies show international doctors fill critical gaps rather than displace American physicians.

title: Confederate statue torn down during anti-racism protests reinstalled in Washington
reference_summary: President Donald Trump ordered the reinstallation of statue of Confederate Gen. Albert Pike in Washington, D.C., which had been torn down by racial-justice protesters in 2020 after the killing of George Floyd. The National Park Service says it returned the restored 1901 statue under Trump's executive order to “restore” historical monuments. Democratic Delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton condemned the move as “offensive,” arguing Pike served dishonorably against the U.S. and that Confederate statues belong in museums, not public parks. Pike's statue had long been controversial — local officials had tried for decades to remove it — and it was the only Confederate general monument in the U.S. capital prior to its toppling. Trump has directed the return of Confederate statues and paintings since returning to office.

title: Jamaica comienza a sentir la inminente llegada del “catastrófico” huracán 'Melissa', que deja ya tres muertos
reference_summary: Hurricane Melissa, now a Category 5 and one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes ever recorded, is approaching Jamaica with sustained winds of about 174 mph. The Jamaican government has ordered mass evacuations, warning that no infrastructure in the region can withstand a storm of this magnitude, and at least three deaths have already been reported even before landfall. The storm is expected to bring extreme rainfall, storm surges up to four meters, widespread flooding, and major damage to power, airports, and roads. Airports are closed, shelters are overwhelmed or unprepared, and tens of thousands are already without electricity. After crossing Jamaica, Melissa is expected to move toward Cuba, Turks and Caicos, and the Bahamas.

title: La jefa de Emergencias admite a la jueza que el Cecopi ya debatía el ES-Alert por la dana a las 18.35 horas cuando el Gobierno lo pidiÃ³
reference_summary: A senior emergency official in Valencia, Inmaculada Piles, testified to a judge that technicians began preparing a mobile emergency alert (ES-Alert) at 6:35 pm on the day of massive flooding in and around Valencia, Spain, on October 29, 2024 — 90 minutes before it was actually sent. Because the alert was not issued until 8:11 pm, the judge believes the delay contributed to most of the 229 deaths during the catastrophic floods. Piles said the government delegation requested the alert, and messages show Generalitat officials agreed and began drafting it. She also criticized Spain's weather agency for providing only generic and low-level warnings beforehand. According to sources linked to the accused former regional minister, both the national government and regional authorities participated in preparing the alert, contradicting claims that Madrid was uninvolved.

title: Israel bombardea Gaza después de acusar a Hamás de atacar a sus tropas
reference_summary: Israel resumed air strikes on Gaza on Tuesday after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ordered “immediate” and “forceful” attacks following an assault on Israeli troops near Rafah and the delivery of remains that did not match the list of 13 hostages still unreturned. Health authorities said the renewed strikes killed at least eight people (three in Gaza City and five in Khan Yunis), while Israel's defense minister Israel Katz vowed “Hamas will pay a high price for attacking soldiers of the Israeli Defense Forces in Gaza.” Hamas denies attacking Israeli forces since the ceasefire began on October 10. The International Committee of the Red Cross criticized Hamas over footage suggesting it staged the recovery of one body, while Hamas says it remains committed to the ceasefire while blaming Israeli violations for delaying further handovers. U.S. officials signaled limited public pushback. Vice President J.D. Vance said “the ceasefire is holding” and Secretary of State Marco Rubio affirmed Israel's right to self-defense, while President Trump warned Hamas to return bodies quickly or face consequences.

title: Miles de estudiantes salen a la calle para protestar contra el 'bullying': “Esto no es un juego de niños”
reference_summary: Thousands of students and parents marched in Seville and across Spain to protest school bullying after the suicide of Sandra Peña, a 14-year-old whose school failed to initiate anti-bullying protocols despite repeated warnings. Many teenagers at the demonstration shared their own experiences with bullying, saying that in some cases protocols worked, but in others — like Sandra's — schools minimized or ignored the abuse. Sandra's family and classmates attended, demanding accountability. Investigations are now underway by the juvenile prosecutor's office, children's rights authorities, and labor inspectors. Protesters argued that schools often prioritize their reputation over student safety and called for systemic changes so no student faces bullying alone again.

title: El Gobierno aprueba avales y nuevas ayudas por valor de 6.000 millones de euros para los afectados por la dana
reference_summary: Spain's Council of Ministers approved a new decree expanding aid for reconstruction after the devastating October 2024 floods in Valencia, adding up to €6 billion in guarantees and assistance. This package extends previous aid that the government says already exceeds €8 billion and includes new ICO financing lines (€750 million), grants for small businesses (€180 million), and a €5 billion guarantee program available through 2040. The decree also prolongs special benefits for self-employed workers, offers Social Security payment deferrals at reduced interest, and expands vehicle-replacement subsidies and housing assistance for flood-affected families. Funds will support relocating residents from flood-risk areas, rebuilding infrastructure with up to 100% cost coverage, and providing aid to cultural and social-service sectors.

title: Melissa, un huracán 'de manual' en tiempos de crisis climática
reference_summary: The World Meteorological Organization calls Hurricane Melissa “the storm of the century for Jamaica,” as the Category 5 cyclone rapidly intensified from Category 1 to Category 5 in about 48 hours, with winds nearly tripling to near 186 mph and forward speed around 6.8 mph. Experts Rodney Martínez of the WMO and Cuban meteorologist José Rubiera say the storm's explosive growth and slow movement are textbook outcomes of climate change and warmed seas, warning of catastrophic rainfall, storm surge, and landslides on Jamaica's mountainous terrain. Jamaica and Cuba activated early-warning and evacuation measures. Airports closed in Jamaica, and Cuba is prepositioning aid while its utility authority plans controlled shutdowns of power plants. The Red Cross estimates at least 1.5 million Jamaicans will be directly affected, and UNICEF says up to 1.6 million children are at risk across the Caribbean. Three deaths in Jamaica were reported by midday Tuesday. The UN will release $4 million from its emergency fund to support preventative measures for 170,000 people in eastern Cuba.

title: Por qué Rosalía ha elegido estas marcas de moda para el relato místico de 'Berghain'
reference_summary: Spanish singer-songwriter Rosalía launches her new era with 'Lux' and the single “Berghain,” leaning heavily into religious and mystical symbolism — not just in lyrics, but through fashion as narrative. Fans noticed her months-long embrace of all-white looks, foreshadowing themes of purity, redemption, and transcendence. The “Berghain” video, styled with rare archival pieces by Alexander McQueen, Givenchy, Balenciaga, and emerging designers, functions like visual theology: she moves from black (pain and chaos) to gray (transition) to white (rebirth). Every garment carries symbolic weight, including McQueen's rosary-inspired sandals and a modern “nun” aesthetic in press materials. While archival fashion can feel trend-chasing for other artists, Rosalía turns it into storytelling—each outfit is a chapter in her personal myth.

title: La jefa del 112 admite a la jueza de la dana que el Gobierno central le pidió a las 18.35 el envío de la alerta
reference_summary: In testimony about Valencia's October 29, 2024 flood disaster, 112 emergency services chief Inmaculada Piles said Spain's central government asked at 6:35 pm to send an ES-Alert to residents, but the regional government didn't issue it until 8:11 pm — by which time many victims had already died. She described confusion inside Spain's emergency management center, Cecopi, with a jammed 112 line ( about 20,000 calls) and poor interpretation of raw hydrology and weather data. Her account undercuts claims of an “information blackout” and indicates the regional presidency knew the scale by midday, even as the president kept his public schedule. The judge leading the probe argues an earlier alert could have saved lives.

title: La negociación por Gaza comienza en Egipto e Israel llora el 7 de octubre
reference_summary: Israel marks the second anniversary of Hamas's October 7, 2023 attacks as new negotiations begin in Egypt, aiming to end the war that has killed more than 67,000 people in Gaza. Families of victims and hostages are holding vigils, while one major organization even proposes President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize for pushing a 20-point deal. The plan, signed by Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu in Washington on October 9, would halt Israeli bombing, withdraw troops gradually, and see Hamas free all remaining hostages, disarm, and hand control of Gaza to a reformed Palestinian Authority — potentially opening the door to a future Palestinian state. Major disputes remain, including Hamas's demand for amnesty even for militants involved in the 2023 massacre, as well as pressure from ultrareligious parties in Israel who reject concessions. Despite the talks, Israeli strikes have continued, killing more civilians, while negotiators from Israel, Hamas, and the U.S. try to push a rare opening toward a peace settlement amid collective exhaustion from the war.

title: Moncloa se conjura tras el portazo de Puigdemont que deja a Sánchez sin mayoría para gobernar: 'Vamos a seguir lo que queda, hasta 2027'
reference_summary: Former Catalan President Carles Puigdemont announced that his center-right pro-independence party, Together for Catalonia (shortened to “Junts” in Catalan) is cutting ties with Spain's ruling Socialist Workers' Party, but without ending the government. The Spanish prime minister's office frames it as “damage control,” arguing that the reality remains largely the same: the government must negotiate every vote, one by one, with no guaranteed majority. After losing both Junts and the democratic-socialist Podemos over the past two years, Spain's ruling coalition now faces what the Basque Nationalist Party calls a “negative majority,” and chances of passing new national budgets are nearly extinct. Despite this fragility, the government insists it will finish the term through 2027 and continues to offer Junts an open hand, highlighting dialogue and agreements already fulfilled. Ministers publicly stress that the coalition is still governing — having won 88% of parliamentary votes so far — and push the narrative that the agenda will move forward through negotiation.

title: Leo Harlem sorprende en 'El Hormiguero' al anunciar su 'jubilación': 'Necesito parar un poquito y ponerme bien de salud'
reference_summary: Spanish comedian Leo Harlem returned to the TV show 'El Hormiguero' as part of its special programming celebrating 3,000 episodes. He showed off a theater award he had just received and used the moment to highlight the value of comedians in entertainment. During the interview, host Pablo Motos asked him if it was true that Harlem is retiring. Harlem confirmed that starting January 1 he will slow down professionally, leaving behind his hectic touring life. Instead, he plans to focus on a single project, 'Leo Talks,' and enjoy a calmer stage of life. Nearing age 63, he joked that even his suitcase “needs a rest” after years of constant travel. He won't disappear entirely; he'll still participate in charity shows. He also wants to explore new hobbies: learning electric guitar (depending on the electricity bill, he joked) or returning to drawing and painting classes.

title: Hamas, Palestina y la derrota de Israel tras dos años de exterminio en Gaza
reference_summary: In the two years since Hamas attacked southern Israel on October 7, 2023, killing 1,200 people and taking 251 hostages, Israel's military campaign has devastated Gaza, with a UN report describing the resulting conflict as genocide and citing more than 67,000 Palestinians killed and entire cities destroyed. The offensive has empowered ultranationalist ministers in Israel's government and split Israeli society over the war's direction and the fate of the hostages. While the United States has backed Israel militarily, 152 countries recognize Palestine and see the conflict through the lens of colonialism and failed international intervention. President Donald Trump has proposed a deal involving hostage-prisoner exchanges, a ceasefire, and international reconstruction of Gaza, though it does not resolve the issue of Palestinian statehood.

title: La educación, la mayor prioridad tras la tregua en Gaza: "Miles de niños han sido privados de su niñez"
reference_summary: More than 500,000 children in Gaza have been displaced during two years of war, and about 64,000 have been killed or injured, according to UN data. UNICEF officials in Gaza say at least 58,000 children are now “unaccompanied,” having lost one or both parents, and 90% show signs of PTSD after repeated displacement and trauma. The ceasefire declared on October 10 has allowed humanitarian groups to assess damage: 85% of schools are destroyed or unusable, and many remaining buildings are being used as shelters. Temporary learning centers currently reach 100,000 children, but materials are scarce and education is largely absent from incoming aid shipments. UNICEF warns that restoring education and psychological support is critical, as Gaza's children face an uncertain future in a largely uninhabitable enclave.

title: Al menos 64 muertos y 81 detenidos en una operación contra el narcotráfico en Río de Janeiro
reference_summary: A massive police raid in the Alemão and Penha favela complexes in northern Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday left around 120 people dead, including four police officers, making it the deadliest police operation in the city's history. The operation targeted the Comando Vermelho (CV) criminal faction and involved 2,500 officers, helicopters, armored vehicles, and over 100 arrest warrants. Traffickers responded with gunfire, burning barricades, and drones carrying explosives, shutting down schools, hospitals, and major roads. Human Rights Watch called the operation a “huge tragedy” and urged investigations into each death and the planning behind the raid. Authorities say the goal was to capture CV leadership and stop its territorial expansion; prosecutors have charged 67 people with drug-trafficking association.

title: Una asociación de víctimas de la dana denuncia el intento de "silenciar la verdad emocional" al excluir a los fotoperiodistas en el funeral de Estado
reference_summary: A group representing those affected by the October 2024 flood denounced the Spanish government for barring independent photojournalists from Wednesday's state funeral in Valencia for the victims. The group says the restrictions — allowing only official photographers from the royal household, the Prime Minister's office, and the Agencia EFE, a Spanish international news agency — attempt to “silence the emotional truth” and prevent free press coverage. They argue that photojournalists have treated families with “respect and sensitivity” throughout the year and demand full access inside the venue, not confinement hundreds of meters away. The association will not attend as a collective; only affected families will. The controversy has grown, and the government may reconsider its decision.

title: Responsables de los pagos en el PSOE sitúan a Koldo como la persona clave: "Venía él, su mujer o un mensajero. Yo dejaba un sobre en la recepción de Ferraz para que pasaran a por él"
reference_summary: Two former administrators for the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party told Spain's Supreme Court that Koldo García, former adviser to José Luis Ábalos, was the person who routinely collected and distributed cash reimbursements for the party's Organization department. They said expenses were handed over in envelopes, sometimes picked up by García, his wife, or even a courier, without itemizing who the money was for or what the expenses were. A Civil Guard report found unexplained discrepancies and missing documentation in those expenses submitted to the court. The judge questioned the lack of controls, and the anti-corruption prosecutor asked about whether high-value €500 bills were handled. One witness, a former manager, denied it, and the other, a former secretary, said she could not recall recent cash movements.

title: Dónde ver Palma del Río - Betis: canal de TV y streaming online del partido de la Copa del Rey 2025-2026
reference_summary: Real Betis will face Atlético Palma del Río this Thursday, October 30 at 9 pm, in the first round of the 2025-26 Copa del Rey at the Estadio Sergio León in Córdoba. The match will air on Movistar Plus and Movistar LaLiga 4, with live updates on Alfinaldelapalmera.com and ABC de Sevilla. Betis, coming off a 2-0 league loss to Atlético Madrid, is expected to rotate players — giving minutes to Adrián, Ángel Ortiz, Pablo García, Llorente, and Chimy Ávila — while only Isco remains injured. Host club Palma del Río, led by former Betis striker Sergio León, competes in the Andalusian Division of Honor and expanded its stadium to 8,000 seats for the sold-out game.

title: Ataques aéreos de Israel en la Franja de Gaza tras los disparos contra sus tropas y la ddevolución errónea de los restos de un rehén
reference_summary: Israel briefly resumed airstrikes in Gaza on Tuesday after a Palestinian armed attack in Rafah killed an Israeli reservist, triggering strikes that the Gaza Health Ministry says left at least 100 Palestinians dead, including 35 children and 7 women. Israel said it targeted “dozens of terror sites” in response to what it called Hamas violations of the Trump-brokered ceasefire, while Hamas and Islamic Jihad accused Israel of breaking the truce first. The clashes led Hamas to cancel the planned handover of another Israeli hostage, keeping the remaining total at 13, after earlier exchanges that saw 20 hostages returned and 250 Palestinian prisoners released. U.S. officials, including Vice President J.D. Vance, insist the ceasefire remains in effect and said Washington was notified in advance of Israel's military response. Israel's government faces internal pressure to abandon the ceasefire, but officials admit military actions now require approval from the Trump administration, which is overseeing the truce.

title: El PSOE revela ahora que entregó 127.000 euros al equipo de Ábalos en "liquidaciones" en metálico "no siempre individualizadas"
reference_summary: The Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) told Spain's Supreme Court that all payments made by its Organization departmnet — including cash — were properly recorded in party accounts and audited. The party acknowledged spending about €1 million in cash between 2017 and 2021 and distributing €127,000 to lawmaker José Luis Ábalos's team, sometimes without itemized receipts, submitting expenses collectively instead. The PSOE said it is “possible” that Koldo García handled some of the cash distributions but insisted the money was not paid to García, Ábalos, or current Organization Secretary Santos Cerdán personally. The party stated that cash withdrawals came only from a BBVA operating account, involved no €500 bills, and denied the existence of any “Safe B” or off-the-books fund.

title: Mazón, en el aniversario del 29-O: “Hubo cosas que debieron funcionar mejor, debemos reflexionar”
reference_summary: Valencian regional president Carlos Mazón marked the one-year anniversary of the October 29 flood disaster — which killed 229 people — by reading an institutional statement acknowledging that “things should have worked better” that day. He said authorities “tried to do our best in an unimaginable situation, but in many cases it was not enough,” while urging that the day not be used for political confrontation. The regional government officially declared 29 October a permanent day of remembrance and mourning across the three provinces. At a formal ceremony attended by the full cabinet and senior officials, Mazón emphasized honoring the victims' memory and the solidarity shown by society after the catastrophe.
